abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey a satisfactory project
            outcome, likely sustainability, but modest institutional
            development impacts. Among the many lessons learned, the
            need for legal and regulatory framework, in all its
            dimensions, is the necessary foundation for the banking
            environment to succeed. From an internal point of view,
            future Bank operations, replicated on this model, would
            require further adjustments in current policy and practices.
            From a practical point of view, standard disbursement
            schedules can not be applied to projects where private
            sector actors have total control over decision spending:
            current loan disbursement arrangements are based on a
            predetermined schedule, namely, creating pressures that
            undermine prudent credit decisions by private lenders.
            Notwithstanding, the most important policy issue revealed by
            this project is that any attempt to create a market-based
            system for financing public investment can not be in direct
            competition with non-market funding sources (including from
            the Bank) if it is to succeed. This means that there is need
            for an explicit policy on which public entities are entitled
            to receive subsidized loans, and for what purposes.
